content.title: Images from Two Mirrors
content.description: This simulation shows the images formed by two mirrors. The green "L" is the object. If the angle between the two mirrors is \(\frac{360^\circ}{n}\), then \(n-1\) virtual images (the orange L's) will be formed. You can drag the endpoint of the mirror to change the angle between them.

content.title: Parabolic Mirror
content.description: This simulation demonstrates the focusing property of the parabolic mirror.

content.title: Penrose unilluminable room
content.description: The Penrose unilluminable room is constructed from elliptic, circular, and linear mirrors. It has the interesting property that a point source (green) within the room will not shine the entire room, no matter where you put it. You can drag the green point to move the source.

content.title: Reflection and Refraction
content.description: This simulation shows the reflection and refraction at a surface.

content.title: Internal Reflection
content.description: This simulation shows the refraction and internal reflection at a surface.

content.title: Prisms
content.description: This simulation demonstrates the right-angle prism, the Porro prism, the rhomboid prism, the Dove prism, and the pentaprism.

content.title: Apparent Depth
content.description: This simulation shows the apparent depth (the distance between the observed image and the water surface) of an object underwater, which is less than the actual depth (the distance between the object and the water surface). The apparent depth depends on the position of the observer, which can be demonstrated by dragging the blue circle.

content.title: Chromatic dispersion
content.description: This simulation demonstrates chromatic dispersion using a white-colored beam and a triangular prism. Here the white color is formed by mixing red, orange, yellow, green, cyan, blue, and violet colors.

content.title: Rainbows
content.description: This simulation demonstrates the formation of the primary rainbow, the secondary rainbow, and Alexandar's dark band. Here the spectrum of the sunlight is approximated by mixing red, orange, yellow, green, cyan, blue, and violet colors.

content.title: Aplanatic points
content.description:
Aplanatic points of an optical system are special points on its optical axis, such that "rays proceeding from one of them will all converge to, or seen to diverge from the other point".

Ellipse: the two foci of the elliptical lens/mirror are aplanatic points, since light emitted from one focus will converge towards the other.

Sphere: a spherical lens has two aplanatic points, inside and outside the sphere - for more details see the simulation.

Hyperbola: the two foci of the Hyperbolic mirror simulation are also aplanatic points.


Given two points with horizontal coordinates \(x_1\) and \(x_2\), and given the refractive index outside and inside our optical element as \(n_1\) and \(n_2\) (respectively), for this two points to be aplanatic points - the boundary of our optical element must fulfill the following equation:
\(k_1 n_1 \sqrt{ (x - x_1)^2 + y^2} + k_2 n_2 \sqrt{ (x - x_2)^2 + y^2} = n_1 |x_1| + n_2 |x_2|\)
such that \(k_i=1\) or \(-1\) if the ray connecting \(x_i\) and the boundary of our optical element is real or imaginary, respectively.
This is an equation of a Cartesian oval, of which the conic sections are special cases.

content.title: Concave Lens
content.description: This simulation shows a concave lens diverging a beam.

content.title: Convex Lens
content.description: This simulation shows a convex lens converging a beam.

content.title: Lens Images
content.description: This simulation shows the images of a beam and point sources produced by ideal lenses.

content.title: Vanishing point
content.description:
Some optical systems map infinite parallel lines, to lines on the image plane which meet at a single point, making an illusion that the parallel lines meet "at infinity". This single point is called the vanishing point.

For an optical system comprising an ideal lens with focal length \(f\), located on the \(XY\) plane, such that itâ€™s optical axis coincides with the \(X\)(horizontal) axis and the lens coincides with the \(Y\) axis, the vanishing point for a line with a slope \(m\), located at \(x<0\), is given by the \((x,y)\) coordinates \((f,m f)\) .

content.title: Chromatic aberration
content.description: This simulation shows the chromatic aberration of a spherical lens. Here the white color is formed by mixing red, orange, yellow, green, cyan, blue, and violet colors. The focal length of red light is the largest, and that of violet light is the smallest.

content.title: Compound Microscope
content.description: This simulation demonstrates the compound microscope. The object (green) is very near the axis, representing a small object. The object is magnified by the two lenses so that a large inverted virtual image (the intersection of the final orange extensions) is produced.

content.title: Rochester cloak
content.description: Rochester cloak is a type of cloaking device, which uses only 4 lenses. In the version presented in this simulation, the focal length of the two external lenses is \(f_1\), and of the two mid lenses is \(f_2\), such that the distance between consecutive lenses of focal lengths \(f_1\) and \(f_2\) equals \(t_1=f_1+f_2\), and the distance between the mid lenses is \(t_2=2f_2\frac{f1+f2}{f1-f2}\).

content.title: Single Ray demo
content.description: This simulation demonstrates the reflection and refraction of a single ray.

content.title: Spherical Lens and Mirror
content.description: This simulation shows a continuous beam passing through a spherical lens and a spherical mirror.

content.title: NL Binoculars
content.description: This simulation shows a rough sketch of Swarovski NL binoculars.

content.title: Einstein Ring refocused to Single Image via Eyepiece
content.description: This simulation models an eyepiece/lens that could be used on any scientific telescope which will reverse the "halo" and focus an Einstein ring back into its original form while scattering the light of any star or massive object used to create the ring.

content.title: "Black cat becomes white" demo
content.description: "Black cat becomes white" is a popular science demo in which some part of a figure disappears when put in water. It is made with the following steps: (1) Draw a figure (e.g. a black cat) on a piece of paper. (2) Put the paper in a plastic zip-lock bag. (3) Draw part of the figure (e.g. the border of the cat) or some other figure on the plastic surface. When put in water, the figure drawn on the paper disappears, but not the part drawn on the plastic surface.
